thoughtText: Showcase your projects on GitHub or a personal website. Highlight your best work, including code samples, live demos, and descriptions of your projects.
Focus on core programming concepts like data structures, algorithms, and object-oriented programming. Employers look for a solid understanding of the basics.
Collaborating on open-source projects helps you gain real-world experience and allows employers to see your code and teamwork in action.
Attend local meetups, join online communities, and participate in hackathons to build a network of contacts in the tech industry.
Sites like LeetCode, HackerRank, and Codewars offer coding challenges that can help improve your problem-solving skills and prepare you for technical interviews.
Many companies want to know how you work in a team, handle conflict, and approach learning. Practice answering behavioral questions to show soft skills.
Work on projects that solve real problems or serve a specific niche. These projects can showcase your practical skills to potential employers.
Build a professional LinkedIn profile and connect with people in the industry. Recruiters often use LinkedIn to find candidates for tech roles.
Have mock interviews with friends or use platforms like Pramp to practice technical and behavioral interview questions.
Passion for coding and technology is often more important than extensive experience. Demonstrate your love for learning and building things in interviews and applications.
